publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

div.fw: [––1] one stroke can be seen; it could also be ‘2’ or ‘3’

seg.seg: I have not been able to satiate [this] ocean of the sense[s]; [that] is my fault. [10b] On the path of [my] own deed[s] [my] relatives have gone separated from me, they have forgotten me. [10c] Alone I expel

(evil). May there be shame on me for the attempt of [any] evil [deed]. 10[d] O lord, o omniscient, o compassionate one! O [you] who let go all offences of the erring beings! [11a] Towards you again I stretch the palms [of my hands].
Be a spokesman for me before the beings! May they let go my offence! [11b] I see my fault. I turn away from evil because of this in all births. [11c] And may I permamently enjoy the fruit
Ich kehre um von der Schlechtigkeit hierdurch in allen Geburten.
I turn away from wickedness therefore, in all incarnations.
for their sake even on the Avīci earth. 11[d] [While my] vessels are burnt by the fires of remorse, I dwell like an empty tree [12a] with glowing spirit,
Während die Adern von den Feuern der Reue verbrannt werden, weile ich wie ein ausgehöhlter Baum mit glühendem Geist [und] drücke [meine] Adern bei Tag [und] Nacht.
While [my] veins are burned by the fires of remorse, I tarry like a hollowed tree with a glowing spirit [and] press my veins by day [and] night.
[and] I press my vessels day and night. [12b] Would the flames of hell drag me with this human body into the Avīci hell? [12c] But may my mind be satiated with terrible passions;
Would the flames of hell drag me with this human body into the Avīci hell? But may my mind be satiated with terrible passions;457 may it be completely under control!
may it be completely under control! 12[d] O compassionate one, o pitying one, I shelter with you, I call on you with a wish and with confidence. [13a] Apart from you, I don't find anybody
O Barmherziger, Mitleidiger! Ich schreie [und] rufe dich in dem Wunsch voll von Vertrauen.
Oh compassionate one, oh pitying one, I cry [and] call you with [my] wish and full of trust.
to seek refuge in in this time. [13b] Smashed on the head by passions, I [have] certainly given up this terrible self. [13c] Fill up the hollow of compassion!
Fill up the hollow of compassion! Therein I will hide, in your protection, father, so that my fear will rest! (cf 322–323, 328)
Therein I will hide, in your protection, father, so that my fear will rest! 13[d] Not even once in the births have I got to hear [this] name, and therefore afterwards, [14a] lacking a good teacher,
I have not once stood back because of evil. [14b] With the fires of shame and repentence I burn the base of life and it does not block me [anymore]. [14c] I fall onto your protection. May
Mit den Feuern von Reue [und] Scham verbrenne ich die Lebensgrundlage, und nicht umschließt sie(?) mich mehr.
With the fire of remorse [and] shame I burn the foundation of life and it(?) does not cling about me anymore.
Möge das Karman mir schwinden [und] von mir abgerieben werden!
May my karma disappear [and] be rubbed off me!
my deed disappear! May it be wiped out! May there be forgiveness for me! 14[d] Who has taken excellent protection in you, his bad deed disappeared through your protection. [15a] The king of Magadha,
Von schlechten Freunden aufgestachelt, tötete der König (von) Magadha [seinen] guten Vater. Zu deinen Füßen bemühte er sich, sah den Fehler ein [und] erlangte vom Bösen Reinigung.
Incited by wicked friends, the king (of) Magadha killed [his] god father. At your feet he exerted himself, saw the error [and] obtained cleansing of evil.
incited by evil friends, killed his good father. [15b] At your feet he made effort, recognised (lit. thought) [his] fault [and] [keeping away] from evil he obtained purity. [15c] Comparable to that I
tell my own sorrow too – may there be forgiveness for me! 15[d] May there be a deed of threefold virtue for me in the saṃsāra without beginning. [16a] To another I (?) went ...

p.note: on line number: one stroke can be seen; it could also be ‘2’ or ‘3’

Although virāma is in many cases correctly written in this manuscript, it is lacking in a number of cases where it is required by the metre: ṣpä a4, a5 read ṣp; pästä a6 read päst; ṣä b2 read ṣ; krentä b2 read krent; tākoy-ñä b4, b6 read tākoy-ñ. Also kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ b3 has to be read as kwīp=-onmiṣṣeṃ.

In several cases metrical sandhi is already written in the manuscript: poyśi =ñmālaṣka a2 for poyśi añmālaṣka; karuṇīka =ñmālaṣ(k)a (because of the metre it cannot be karuṇīk= añmālaṣ(k)a, pace 185, 322) a6 for karuṇīka añmālaṣ(k)a; pk(w)alñemp= eṣe a6 for pk(w)alñempa eṣe, kalp= āstarñe b5 for kalpa astarñe; lakl= a(ñma)ntse b5-6 for lakle a(ñma)ntse. The narrative part of strophe 15 contains two metrical irregularities: walo māga(tṣe) yolaiṃ b4-5 with 5+2 syllables instead 4+3 (the restoration to māga(tṣe) seems nevertheless correct); and likewise wāṣmots ṣeṣartu kausa with 5+2 syllables instead 4+3.

[a1](i)ntriṣṣe samuddär ¦ mā soyässi cämyāwa ¦ nesañ nāki : [10b] ṣañ yāmorṣṣai ytārisa ¦ waiptār maiytar-ñ cai ṣñaṣṣi ¦ ñiś märsāre : [10c] ṣesk(e yolo)[a2]lyutaskau ¦ po yolainäts smāntsa ñiś ¦ kwīpe tākoy 10saswa poyśi =ñmālaṣka ¦ po träṅkonta tärkaucai ¦ trikṣaiṃ wnolmets : [11a] ciś yak raksau a(lyi)[a3]ne ¦ weñmo ptākañ onolmeṃ(ts ¦ tä)rko-ñ traṅko : [11b] nāki lkāskau klautkomar ¦ yolaiñemeṃ tesa mant ¦ po cmelane : [11c] awiśäṣṣai kentsa ka[a4]ṣpä ¦ śāśwat oko warpoymar ¦ ce(ṃ)ts pakāna : 11onmiṣṣana pwārasa ¦ tsäksemane marmanma ¦ troṅktse stām ra : [12a] sälpi-ñ cittsa wo[a5]lokmar ¦ nuskaskemar marmanma ¦ iṅkauṃ kästwer : [12b] tā ka ṣpä śāmñai kektseñtsa ¦ nraiṣṣi sl(e)mi pannoṃ ñiś ¦ eṃṣky āwiśne : [12c] empelona kleśanma[a6]¦ mai no pals(k)o soyi pästä ¦ sañāt tākoy 12karuṇīk= añmālaṣ(k)a ¦ (t)auko-(c) kwāmar-(c) akālksa ¦ pk(w)alñemp= eṣe : [13a] cisa parna man(t)a k(c)a[b1]¦ (wa)st(e) y(ā)mts(i) kälpāsk(au) ¦ tā pr(e)śy(ai)yne : [13b] āś papyāku kleśanmats ¦ a(t)ts(ai)k ṣ(a)ñ āñm r(e)r(i)nu ¦ ñiś empele [13c] karuṇaṣṣe tr(o)ṅk prutk(a)r[b2]¦ tune taukau-c saim pācer ¦ lāma-ñ prosko 13mā ṣṣe nta kca cmelane ¦ ñem ra klyaussi kälpāwa ¦ twār ṣä postaññe [14a] krentä käṣṣintsa meṅkitse[b3]¦ yolaiñesa mā ṣṣe nta ¦ aṣkār śmāwa : [14b] kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ pwārasa ¦ tsaksau śmoññai śaulaṣṣai ¦ mā ṣ prutkaṣä-ñ : [14c] ciṣṣe saimäś kloyomar ¦ nau[b4]yto-ñ yāmor kāntoytär-ñ ¦ kṣ(ān)t(i) tākoy-ñä 14cine yāmu śrigupti ¦ yolo yāmor nautā-ne ¦ ciṣṣek saimtsa : [15a] walo māga(tṣe)[b5]yolaiṃ ¦ wāṣmots ṣeṣartu kausa ¦ pātär krent [15b] tañ paiynene spalkāte ¦ nāki palyka yolomeṃ ¦ kalp= āstarñe : [15c] tu menāksa ñiś rano ¦ lakl= a(ñma)[b6]ntse ñiś weskau ¦ deśit tākoy-ñä 15snai yparwecce saṃsārne ¦ täryā-yäkne kärtseṣṣe ¦ yāmor tākoy-ñä : [16a] alyek yey(mä) a –
According to 185 "[t]he manuscript consists of two parts ... A.30 is the left portion and ... A.26 forms the right part ... [w]ritten in medium ductus, it is very clearly preserved."
yāmorṣṣai: a little piece of paper covers the place where the vowel sign of rṣṣai should be, but slight traces of both ai-strokes are still discernible.
=ñmālaṣka: ṣka is added under the line; the addition is marked with a cross above.

smāntsa: the translation of smāṃ follows , who proposes 'test' as the basic meaning. However, his discussion of this passage (55) is not completely satisfactory: he translates 'try', which does not fit well. Further, it is peculiar that the word is preceded by po yolainäts (pace Ogihara l.c., not po yolainats): obviously, the attempt of any single evil deed will already be a shame. Further, his translations of the prs. lyutaskau as 'I shall drive away', and of the opt. tākoy as 'will be' are in my view not correct.

list.item:
[[IDP]]: IOL Toch 5.

Edition: [[Broomhead I]]: 185-187; [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 63-64; [[Peyrot 2007]]: №5.

Complete translation: [[Pinault 2008]]: 327-328, [[Adams 2013]], 5-9.

Translation: full: [[Broomhead I]]: 186-187; a1 [[Carling 2000]]: 93; a1-2 [[Hackstein 1995]]: 243; [[Ogihara 2011a]]: 55; a2-3 [[Hackstein 1995]]: 117; a3 [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 273; a3-4 [[Carling 2000]]: 51, [[Carling 2000]]: 79; a4 [[Hackstein 1995]]: 90, [[Thomas 1968]]: 204, a4-5 [[Hackstein 1995]]: 181, [[Krause, WTG]]: 46, [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 276, 323f; [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 359; a5 [[Carling 2000]]: 344, [[Thomas 1969c]]: 201; a5-6 [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 359; a6 [[Carling 2000]]: 337, [[Krause, WTG]]: 64, [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 95f, [[Thomas 1972]]: 456; a6-b1 [[Carling 2000]]: 289; [[Meunier 2013]]: 144; b1 [[Krause, WTG]]: 32, [[Thomas 1983]]: 8; [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 324; b2 [[Thomas 1954]]: 716; b3 [[Carling 2000]]: 241, [[Hackstein 1995]]: 90, [[Meunier 2013]]: 145, [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 133, [[Thomas 1970]]: 278; b3-4 [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 207, [[Meunier 2013]]: 152; b4 [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 64; b4-5 [[Thomas 1970]]: 278, [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 176; b5 [[Krause, WTG]]: 182.

.

a1 -ntriṣṣe samuddä_r\• mā soyässi cämyāwa nesañä\ nāki : ṣañä\ yāmorṣṣ[ai] ytārisa waiptār maiytar-ñä\ c[ai] ṣñaṣṣi ñ[i]śä\ _m_arsāre : ṣesk· (– –) a2 lyutaskau po yolainät_s\• smāntsa ñiśä\ kwīpe tākoyä\ 10 saswa poyśi =ñmālaṣka po t_r_aṅkonta _t_arkaucai trikṣaiṃ wnolmet_s\• : ciś ya_k\• raksau a (–) a3 -ne weñmo ptākañä\ onolmeṃ[–\]• – rko-ñä\ traṅko : nāki lkāskau klautkoma_r\• yolaiñemeṃ tesa man_t\• po cmelane : awi_ś_aṣṣai kentsa ka a4 _ṣ[_p_a] śāśwa_t\• oko warpoyma_r\• c[e·]t_s\• pakāna : 10-1 onmiṣṣana pwārasa t_s_aksemane marmanma troṅktse stām ra : _s_alp[i]-ñ cittsa wo- a5 -lokma_r\• nuskaskema_r\• marmanma iṅkauṃ _k_astwe_r\• : tā ka _ṣ_p_a śāmñai kektseñtsa nraiṣṣi [s]l·mi pannoṃ ñiśä\ eṃṣky āwiśne : empelona kleśanma a6 [mai] no pal[s·]o soyi _p_as_t_a sañāt tākoyä\ 10-2 kar[u]ṇīka =ñmālaṣ·a ·au[k]o-·ä\ kwā[ma]r-·ä\ akālk[s]a pk·alñemp= eṣe : cisa parna man·a k·a b1 – st· [y·]mts· _k_alpāsk· tā pr·śy·yn[e] : ā_ś\• papyāku kleśanmat_s\• a[·ts· _k\] [ṣ·]ñ ā[ñ]_m[\] r·r·nu ñ[i]śä\ empel[e] karuṇaṣṣe tr·ṅ_k\ prutk·_r\ b2 tune taukau-cä\ sai_m\ pāce_r\• lāma-ñä\ prosko 10-3 mā ṣṣe nta kca cmelane ñem ra klyaussi _k_alpāwa twār _ṣ_a postaññe kren_t_a _k_aṣṣintsa meṅkitse b3 [y]olaiñesa mā ṣṣe nta aṣkār śmāwa : kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ pwārasa tsaksau śmoññai śaul[a]ṣṣai mā _ṣ\• prutka_ṣ_a-ñä\ : ciṣṣe sai_m_a_ś\• kloyoma_r\• nau- b4 -yto-ñä\ yāmo_r\• kāntoy_t_ar-ñä\ kṣ··t· tākoy-ñä 10-4 cine yāmu śrigupti yolo yāmo_r\• nautā-ne ciṣṣe_k\• saimtsa : walo māga(–) b5 yolaiṃ wāṣmot_s\• ṣeṣartu kausa pā_t_a_r\• kren_t\• tañä\ paiynene spalkāte nāki palyka yolomeṃ kalp= āstarñe : tu menāksa ñiś rano lakl= a – b6 -ntse ñiśä\ weskau deśi_t\• tākoy-ñä 10-5 snai yparwecce saṃsārne _t_aryā-yäkne _k_artseṣṣe yāmo_r\• tākoy-ñä : alye_k\• yey·· a –

text notes:

a1. yāmorṣṣai: a little piece of paper covers the place where the vowel sign of rṣṣai should be, but slight traces of both ai-strokes are still discernible.
a2. =ñmālaṣka: ṣka is added under the line; the addition is marked with a cross above.
a2. smāntsa: the translation of smāṃ follows [[Ogihara 2011a]], who proposes 'test' as the basic meaning. However, his discussion of this passage ([[Ogihara 2011a]]: 55) is not completely satisfactory: he translates 'try', which does not fit well. Further, it is peculiar that the word is preceded by po yolainäts (pace Ogihara l.c., not po yolainats): obviously, the attempt of any single evil deed will already be a shame. Further, his translations of the prs. lyutaskau as 'I shall drive away', and of the opt. tākoy as 'will be' are in my view not correct.
b3-4. nauyto-ñ: for nautoy-ñ.

notes on the metre:

Although virāma is in many cases correctly written in this manuscript, it is lacking in a number of cases where it is required by the metre: ṣpä a4, a5 read ṣp; pästä a6 read päst; ṣä b2 read ṣ; krentä b2 read krent; tākoy-ñä b4, b6 read tākoy-ñ. Also kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ b3 has to be read as kwīp=-onmiṣṣeṃ.

In several cases metrical sandhi is already written in the manuscript: poyśi =ñmālaṣka a2 for poyśi añmālaṣka; karuṇīka =ñmālaṣ(k)a (because of the metre it cannot be karuṇīk= añmālaṣ(k)a, pace [[Broomhead I]]: 185, [[Pinault 2008]]: 322) a6 for karuṇīka añmālaṣ(k)a; pk(w)alñemp= eṣe a6 for pk(w)alñempa eṣe, kalp= āstarñe b5 for kalpa astarñe; lakl= a(ñma)ntse b5-6 for lakle a(ñma)ntse.
The narrative part of strophe 15 contains two metrical irregularities: walo māga(tṣe) yolaiṃ b4-5 with 5+2 syllables instead 4+3 (the restoration to māga(tṣe) seems nevertheless correct); and likewise wāṣmots ṣeṣartu kausa with 5+2 syllables instead 4+3.

metrical analysis:

[a1] (i)ntriṣṣe samuddär ¦ mā soyässi cämyāwa ¦ nesañ nāki : [10b]
ṣañ yāmorṣṣai ytārisa ¦ waiptār maiytar-ñ cai ṣñaṣṣi ¦ ñiś märsāre : [10c]
ṣesk(e yolo) [a2] lyutaskau ¦ po yolainäts smāntsa ñiś ¦ kwīpe tākoy 10
saswa poyśi =ñmālaṣka ¦ po träṅkonta tärkaucai ¦ trikṣaiṃ wnolmets : [11a]
ciś yak raksau a(lyi)[a3]ne ¦ weñmo ptākañ onolmeṃ(ts ¦ tä)rko-ñ traṅko : [11b]
nāki lkāskau klautkomar ¦ yolaiñemeṃ tesa mant ¦ po cmelane : [11c]
awiśäṣṣai kentsa ka [a4] ṣpä ¦ śāśwat oko warpoymar ¦ ce(ṃ)ts pakāna : 11
onmiṣṣana pwārasa ¦ tsäksemane marmanma ¦ troṅktse stām ra : [12a]
sälpi-ñ cittsa wo[a5]lokmar ¦ nuskaskemar marmanma ¦ iṅkauṃ kästwer : [12b]
tā ka ṣpä śāmñai kektseñtsa ¦ nraiṣṣi sl(e)mi pannoṃ ñiś ¦ eṃṣky āwiśne : [12c]
empelona kleśanma [a6] ¦ mai no pals(k)o soyi pästä ¦ sañāt tākoy 12
karuṇīk= añmālaṣ(k)a ¦ (t)auko-(c) kwāmar-(c) akālksa ¦ pk(w)alñemp= eṣe : [13a]
cisa parna man(t)a k(c)a [b1] ¦ (wa)st(e) y(ā)mts(i) kälpāsk(au) ¦ tā pr(e)śy(ai)yne : [13b]
āś papyāku kleśanmats ¦ a(t)ts(ai)k ṣ(a)ñ āñm r(e)r(i)nu ¦ ñiś empele [13c]
karuṇaṣṣe tr(o)ṅk prutk(a)r [b2] ¦ tune taukau-c saim pācer ¦ lāma-ñ prosko 13
mā ṣṣe nta kca cmelane ¦ ñem ra klyaussi kälpāwa ¦ twār ṣä postaññe [14a]
krentä käṣṣintsa meṅkitse [b3] ¦ yolaiñesa mā ṣṣe nta ¦ aṣkār śmāwa : [14b]
kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ pwārasa ¦ tsaksau śmoññai śaulaṣṣai ¦ mā ṣ prutkaṣä-ñ : [14c]
ciṣṣe saimäś kloyomar ¦ nau[b4]yto-ñ yāmor kāntoytär-ñ ¦ kṣ(ān)t(i) tākoy-ñä 14
cine yāmu śrigupti ¦ yolo yāmor nautā-ne ¦ ciṣṣek saimtsa : [15a]
walo māga(tṣe) [b5] yolaiṃ ¦ wāṣmots ṣeṣartu kausa ¦ pātär krent [15b]
tañ paiynene spalkāte ¦ nāki palyka yolomeṃ ¦ kalp= āstarñe : [15c]
tu menāksa ñiś rano ¦ lakl= a(ñma)[b6]ntse ñiś weskau ¦ deśit tākoy-ñä 15
snai yparwecce saṃsārne ¦ täryā-yäkne kärtseṣṣe ¦ yāmor tākoy-ñä : [16a]
alyek yey(mä) a –

a1 I have not been able to satiate [this] ocean of the sense[s]; [that] is my fault. [10b] On the path of [my] own deed[s] [my] relatives have gone separated from me, they have forgotten me. [10c] Alone I expel a2 (evil). May there be shame on me for the attempt of [any] evil [deed]. 10[d] O lord, o omniscient, o compassionate one! O [you] who let go all offences of the erring beings! [11a] Towards you again I stretch the palms [of my hands]. a3 Be a spokesman for me before the beings! May they let go my offence! [11b] I see my fault. I turn away from evil because of this in all births. [11c] And may I permamently enjoy the fruit a4 for their sake even on the Avīci earth. 11[d] [While my] vessels are burnt by the fires of remorse, I dwell like an empty tree [12a] with glowing spirit, a5 [and] I press my vessels day and night. [12b] Would the flames of hell drag me with this human body into the Avīci hell? [12c] But may my mind be satiated with terrible passions; a6 may it be completely under control! 12[d] O compassionate one, o pitying one, I shelter with you, I call on you with a wish and with confidence. [13a] Apart from you, I don't find anybody b1 to seek refuge in in this time. [13b] Smashed on the head by passions, I [have] certainly given up this terrible self. [13c] Fill up the hollow of compassion! b2 Therein I will hide, in your protection, father, so that my fear will rest! 13[d] Not even once in the births have I got to hear [this] name, and therefore afterwards, [14a] lacking a good teacher, b3 I have not once stood back because of evil. [14b] With the fires of shame and repentence I burn the base of life and it does not block me [anymore]. [14c] I fall onto your protection. May b4 my deed disappear! May it be wiped out! May there be forgiveness for me! 14[d] Who has taken excellent protection in you, his bad deed disappeared through your protection. [15a] The king of Magadha, b5 incited by evil friends, killed his good father. [15b] At your feet he made effort, recognised (lit. thought) [his] fault [and] [keeping away] from evil he obtained purity. [15c] Comparable to that I b6 tell my own sorrow too – may there be forgiveness for me! 15[d] May there be a deed of threefold virtue for me in the saṃsāra without beginning. [16a] To another I (?) went ...

Alternative classifications:
Peyrotclassical ~ late
Malzahn–
Tamai–
Tamai-C14–

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a5-6 Would the flames of hell drag me with this human body into the Avīci hell? But may my mind be satiated with terrible passions;457 may it be completely under control! 359
b1 Fill up the hollow of compassion! Therein I will hide, in your protection, father, so that my fear will rest! (cf [[Pinault 2008]]: 322–323, 328) 324

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Ich kehre um von der Schlechtigkeit hierdurch in allen Geburten. 273
a4-5 Während die Adern von den Feuern der Reue verbrannt werden, weile ich wie ein ausgehöhlter Baum mit glühendem Geist [und] drücke [meine] Adern bei Tag [und] Nacht. 276, 323-4
a6 O Barmherziger, Mitleidiger! Ich schreie [und] rufe dich in dem Wunsch voll von Vertrauen. 95-6
b3 Mit den Feuern von Reue [und] Scham verbrenne ich die Lebensgrundlage, und nicht umschließt sie(?) mich mehr. 133
b3-4 Möge das Karman mir schwinden [und] von mir abgerieben werden! 207
b4-5 Von schlechten Freunden aufgestachelt, tötete der König (von) Magadha [seinen] guten Vater. Zu deinen Füßen bemühte er sich, sah den Fehler ein [und] erlangte vom Bösen Reinigung. 176


[[Broomhead I]]: 186-187 translates (the recto lines ar not numbered, no translation of b3):
I was not able to satisfy the ocean of senses, [that] is my crime. On my own path of deeds those relatives [of mine] went away from me [and] they forgot me. Alone
I shall drive away the crime completely; may I be ashamed at the repetition of evil deeds! 10. O Lord, Omniscient One [and] Compassionate One who liberates the forlorn ones from all [their] crimes I still stretch out my palms to thee.
Be my intercessor among the beings! May [my] crime be taken from me! I recognize my crime [and] I turn away from evil. Such in all the births ...
And even in the avīci-earth may I continually enjoy the fruit for these reasons. My veins are burning with the fire(s) of repentance like a hollow tree. With glowing spirit I roam about, and oppress my veins day [and] night. And even with this human body may the hellish flames draw me right into the avīci-hell.
May my spirit however have its fill of the kleśas [and] obey. O Merciful [and] Compassionate One I call on thee [and] claim from thee in the wish [and] together with trust
b1 I attained at this time to the making of my refuge. Smitten upon the head by the kleśas, having completely devoted myself, the inner depths of compassion had cruelly enclosed me.
b2 Thereupon I call upon thee as [my] refuge; O father [then] fear will cease for me. Not once did I attain in the births even only to hear the name [and] even not finally ... lacking a good teacher.
b3
b4 May the deed disappear for me [and] be relinquished! May I be forgiven! Having made [his] refuge in thee the evil deed disappeared from him, even through thy protection.
b5 Spurred on by evil friends the king of Maghada killed [his own] good father. He exerted himself before thy feet and he recognised his crime. Out of evil he received purity. Likewise I also speak through my own sorrow.
b6 May forgiveness be mine! In the saṃsāra without beginning may the deed of salvation be mine threefold!
According to [[Broomhead I]]: 185 "[t]he manuscript consists of two parts ... A.30 is the left portion and ... A.26 forms the right part ... [w]ritten in medium ductus, it is very clearly preserved."
[––1] one stroke can be seen; it could also be ‘2’ or ‘3’

%1 intriṣṣe|(i)|ntriṣṣe a1 , samudtär|samuddär ; mā soyässi , cämyāwa ; nesañ nāki : #10b ṣañ yāmorṣṣai , ytārisa ; waiptār maitar-ñ|maiytar-ñ , cai ṣñaṣṣi ; ñiś märsāre : #10c ṣesk(e yolo) , a2 lyutaskau ; po yolainäts , smāntsa ñiś ; kwīpe tākoy 10 #10d saswa poyśi , =ñmālaṣka ; po träṅkonta , tärkaucai ; trikṣaiṃ wnolmets : #11a ciśc|ciś yak raksau , alyine|a(lyi)|ne a3 ; weñmo ptākañ , onolmeṃ(ts ; tarko-ñ|tä)rko-ñ traṅko : #11b nāki lkāskau , klautkomar ; yolaiññemeṃ|yolaiñemeṃ , tesa mant ; po cmelane : #11c awiśäṣṣai , kentsa ka a4 ṣpä ; śāśwat oko , warpoymar ; ce(ṃ)ts pakāna : 11 #11d onmiṣṣana , pwārasa ; tsäksemane , marmanma ; troṅktse stām ra : #12a sälpi-ñ cittsa , wolokmar|wo|lokmar a5 , nuskaskemar ; marmanma , iṅkauṃ kästwer : #12b tā ka ṣpä śāmñai , kektseñtsa ; nraiṣṣi sl(e)mi , pannoṃ ñiś ; eṃṣky āwiśne : #12c empelona , kleśanma ; a6 mai no pals(k)o , soyi pästä ; sañāt tākoy 12 #12d karuṇīka , =ñmālaṣ(k)a ; (t)auko-(c) kwāmar-(c) , akālksa ; pk(w)alñemp= eṣe : #13a cisa parna , man(t)a k(c)a ; b1 (wa)st(e) y(ā)mts(i) , kälpāsk(au) ; tā pr(e)śy(ai)yne : #13b āś papyāku , kleśanmats ; a(t)ts(ai)k ṣ(a)ñ āñm , r(e)r(i)nu ; ñiś empele #13c karuṇaṣṣe , tr(o)ṅk prutk(a)r ; b2 tune taukau-c , saim pācer ; lāma-ñ prosko 13 #13d mā ṣṣe nta kca , cmelane ; ñem ra klyaussi , kälpāwa ; twār ṣä postaññe #14a krentä käṣṣintsa , meṅkitse ; b3 yolaiñesa , mā ṣṣe nta ; aṣkār śmāwa : #14b kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ , pwārasa ; tsaksau śmoññai , śaulaṣṣai ; mā ṣ prutkäṣṣä-ñ|prutkaṣä-ñ : #14c ciṣṣe saimäś , kloyomar ; nauyto-ñ|nau|yto-ñ b4 yāmor , kāntoytär-ñ ; kṣ(ān)t(i) tākoy-ñ|tākoy-ñä 14 #14d cine yāmu , śrigupti ; yolo yāmor , nautā-ne ; ciṣṣek saimtsa : #15a walo māga,(tṣe) b5 yolaiṃ ; wāṣmots ṣeṣar,tu kausa ; pātär krent #15b tañ paiynene , spalkāte ; nāki palyka , yolomeṃ ; kalp= āstarñe : #15c tu menāksa , ñiś rano ; lakl= añmantse|a(ñma)|ntse b6 , ñiś weskau ; deśit tākoy-ñ|tākoy-ñä 15 #15d snai yparwecce , saṃsārne ; täryā-yäkne , kärtseṣṣe ; yāmor tākoy-ñ|tākoy-ñä : #16a alyek yey(mä) , a – %13 #16b

div.p:
Alternative classifications:

<citedRange>186-187</citedRange></bibl> translates (the recto lines ar not numbered, no translation of b3): I was not able to satisfy the ocean of senses, [that] is my crime. On my own path of deeds those relatives [of mine] went away from me [and] they forgot me. Alone I shall drive away the crime completely; may I be ashamed at the repetition of evil deeds! 10. O Lord, Omniscient One [and] Compassionate One who liberates the forlorn ones from all [their] crimes I still stretch out my palms to thee. Be my intercessor among the beings! May [my] crime be taken from me! I recognize my crime [and] I turn away from evil. Such in all the births ... And even in the avīci-earth may I continually enjoy the fruit for these reasons. My veins are burning with the fire(s) of repentance like a hollow tree. With glowing spirit I roam about, and oppress my veins day [and] night. And even with this human body may the hellish flames draw me right into the avīci-hell. May my spirit however have its fill of the kleśas [and] obey. O Merciful [and] Compassionate One I call on thee [and] claim from thee in the wish [and] together with trust b1 I attained at this time to the making of my refuge. Smitten upon the head by the kleśas, having completely devoted myself, the inner depths of compassion had cruelly enclosed me. b2 Thereupon I call upon thee as [my] refuge; O father [then] fear will cease for me. Not once did I attain in the births even only to hear the name [and] even not finally ... lacking a good teacher. b3 b4 May the deed disappear for me [and] be relinquished! May I be forgiven! Having made [his] refuge in thee the evil deed disappeared from him, even through thy protection. b5 Spurred on by evil friends the king of Maghada killed [his own] good father. He exerted himself before thy feet and he recognised his crime. Out of evil he received purity. Likewise I also speak through my own sorrow. b6 May forgiveness be mine! In the saṃsāra without beginning may the deed of salvation be mine threefold! </p></project_comment>
